{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and high urine osmolality and sodium concentration. The most common causes of SIADH include malignancy, pulmonary disease, CNS disorders, and drugs. In this patient, the most likely cause of SIADH is her subdural hematoma. The first step in the management of SIADH is fluid restriction, which will decrease the amount of free water available for dilution of the serum sodium. Tolvaptan, a vasopressin receptor antagonist, is used in severe cases of SIADH when fluid restriction is not effective. Desmopressin is used to treat central diabetes insipidus, not SIADH.
